CLARE BALDING ON THE GRAND NATIONAL
It's one of the most open Grand Nationals in years and you could make a case for almost half the field having a chance of glory.


As always there are some wonderful stories behind the runners and riders.


One of the most well-backed horses is Simon, owned by 87-year-old Mercy Rimell.


The great-grandmother's late husband Fred trained four National winners between 1956-1976 and his father Tom also won in the 1930s, so it would be wonderful if jockey Andrew Thornton could make it win number six for the Rimell family.


One horse that has slipped under the radar a little is L'Ami, who could finally give jockey AP McCoy his first National success.


Out of the field, I think he is the horse with the most potential. 


He is only eight years old and could easily go on and win a Cheltenham Gold Cup, which you can't say about many of the others.


Last year's winner Numbersixvalverde is in with a very good shout. 


Throughout history winners of the big race have always had a strong record when they return to Aintree and he should challenge for a place. 


My tip though is the mare Liberthine.


The rumours were that she was in foal (pregnant) and her hormones would be raging in a positive way, but late on Thursday it was revealed that she actually isn't. 


Despite this I still fancy her as jockey Sam Waley-Cohen has a great record over the National fences, even though he has never ridden in the big race itself before, and his mount has proved she likes jumping them. 


My advice to all of you wanting to put a bet on, is to go for a yard that is in good form and a horse that enjoys quicker ground as it's going to be a scorcher here at Aintree on Saturday.


Enjoy the race,


Clare


Clare Balding will present BBC ONE's Grand National coverage from 1310 BST on Saturday. The big race is at 1615 BST.
